text.p: Let's think about the definition of linear independence. Recall that a list of vectors [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; \ldots v_ n\}[/mathjaxinline] in a vector space [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] is linearly independent if the only way to pick scalars [mathjaxinline]a_1, a_2, \ldots a_ n[/mathjaxinline] such that [mathjaxinline]a_1v_1 + a_2v_2 + \ldots + a_ nv_ n = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline] is if [mathjaxinline]a_1 = a_2 = \ldots = a_ n = 0[/mathjaxinline].
Which of the following would be a way to prove that a list [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; \ldots v_ n\}[/mathjaxinline] is linearly independent? Check all that apply.

choice.text: Assume that [mathjaxinline]a_ i = 0[/mathjaxinline] for all [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline] from 1 to [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline], and show [mathjaxinline]a_1v_1 + a_2v_2 + \ldots + a_ nv_ n = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline]

Assume that [mathjaxinline]a_ i \ne 0[/mathjaxinline] for all [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline] from 1 to [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline], and show [mathjaxinline]a_1v_1 + a_2v_2 + \ldots + a_ nv_ n \ne \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline]

Assume that [mathjaxinline]a_ i \ne 0[/mathjaxinline] for at least one [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline] from 1 to [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline], and show [mathjaxinline]a_1v_1 + a_2v_2 + \ldots + a_ nv_ n \ne \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline]

Assume that [mathjaxinline]a_1v_1 + a_2v_2 + \ldots + a_ nv_ n = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline], and show that [mathjaxinline]a_ i = 0[/mathjaxinline] for all [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline] from 1 to [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline]

Assume that [mathjaxinline]a_1v_1 + a_2v_2 + \ldots + a_ nv_ n \ne \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline], and show that [mathjaxinline]a_ i \ne 0[/mathjaxinline] for at least one [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline] from 1 to [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline]
